summary: This is an email chain between federal prosecutors discussing the release of Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy report to his brother, Mark Epstein. The prosecutors detail their coordination with the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) to redact sensitive investigative materials from the report, including the names of prison guards under investigation and a draft FBI witness interview. The document also mentions a handwritten note found in Epstein's cell.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.role: Jeffrey Epstein's brother and next of kin
persons.context: Identified as the next of kin to whom the OCME plans to release the redacted autopsy report of Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.context: An MCC lieutenant who was on duty when Epstein's body was found and who was interviewed by the FBI; a draft 302 of this interview is among the sensitive materials to be redacted.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased inmate and subject of investigation
persons.context: The deceased individual whose autopsy report is the subject of the email. His death by suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) is the focus of the ongoing investigation.

connections.description: Mark Epstein is identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother and next of kin, who is requesting the autopsy report.

events.title: Planned submission of redactions to OCME
events.description: Prosecutors plan to provide their proposed redactions for Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy report to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME).

events.title: Email discussion on autopsy report redactions
events.description: Federal prosecutors discuss via email their strategy for redacting sensitive investigative materials from Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy report before its release to his brother.

events.title: Discovery of handwritten note in Epstein's cell
events.description: A handwritten note listing grievances about prison conditions was found in Jeffrey Epstein's cell at the time of his death. It was assessed by OCME and prosecutors as not being a suicide note.

locations: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME)
keyFacts: Prosecutors obtained Epstein's full autopsy report from OCME, which included materials provided by their investigation, such as a draft FBI 302 of an interview with a key MCC witness (Lt.).

The prosecutors requested OCME to redact sensitive materials—including names of prison guards under investigation, witness statements, and the draft FBI 302—before releasing the report to Mark Epstein, to protect the ongoing criminal investigation.
A handwritten note found in Epstein's cell contained grievances about MCC conditions (food, showers, bugs) but was not considered a suicide note by OCME or the prosecutors.
